p: Ocimum basilicum, an aromatic herb that belongs to the Lamiaceae family and the Nepetoideae subfamily [ 9], has been used in folk medicine for the treatment of gastrointestinal and respiratory diseases [ 10]. This species was also reported as having beneficial effects on kidney malfunctions, warts and worm infestations [ 10]. Various chemical functionalities characteristic of anthocyanins, flavonoids, monoterpenes, phenolic acids and their esters, phenylpropanoid derivatives, phytosterols, tannins, and triterpenes have been identified in different O. basilicum extracts [ 11, 12]. Essential oils extracted from its leaves and flowers can be used as flavouring agents in food, medicine and cosmetics [ 10, 11].
